bibl.title: Letter from S.C. Mead to Mabel H. Lazear, May 22, 1908

div1.p: Mead informs Mabel Lazear that the Dalzell Bill has passed both the Senate and the House.

Dear Mrs. Lazear:
div1.p: Yesterday afternoon we wired you as follows:

“Bill passed Senate by unanimous consent. Awaits
President's signature. Congratulations.”

By long distance telephone, Major Ireland informed us of
the concurrent action by the Senate on the Dalzell Bill, thereby plac-
ing the measure before the President for signature. As President
Roosevelt recommended the legislation to Congress in transmitting the
Memorandum prepared by Surgeon General O'Reilly, we feel confident
that the Bill will meet with his approval.

Our previous letter explained to you how the friends of
yourself and Mrs. Carroll have secured the passage of this legislation
after there was no hope of success by reason of the action of the House
Pension Committee. Hon. E. H. Hinshaw, P. C. Knox, John Dalzell and
Charles Dick have worked heart and soul for the success of the legis-
lation, feeling that Congress should fittingly provide for yourself
and Mrs. Carroll.

Permit us to personally express to you our happiness and
gratification that this Congress, by the passage of the Act in question,
has appropriately recognized the services of Dr. Jesse W. Lazear and
Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear,
- 2 -
Major James Carroll.

For your information we enclose herein a copy of the Dalzell
Bill, as passed by the House of Representatives and United States
Senate.
With kindest personal regards, we remain,
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, THE MERCHANTS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW YORK,
By
S.C. Mead
